review.title: On characterizing Inclusion of Bayesian Networks
review.abstract: Each directed acyclic graph (DAG) over a finite, non-empty set of variables (= nodes) N induces a model of independence over N, which is a list of conditional statements of independence over N. The inclusion problem is how to characterize (graphically speaking) whether all statements of independence in the model induced by a DAG K are included in the model that was induced by a second DAG L. Meek (1997) to assume that this inclusion applies when there is a sequence of DAGs from L to K, so that only certain "legal" arrow reversal and "legal" arrow charging operations are performed to obtain the next DAG in the sequence. In this paper, we give several characterizations of the inclusion of DAG models and verify Meek's assumption in the event that the DAGs K and L differ in at most one adaptation.

metadata.abstractText: The inclusion problem deals with how to characterize (in graphical terms) whether all independence statements in the model in­ duced by a DAG K are in the model induced by a second DAG L. Meek (1997) conjec­ tured that this inclusion holds iff there exists a sequence of DAGs from L to K such that only certain 'legal' arrow reversal and 'legal' arrow adding operations are performed to get the next DAG in the sequence. In this paper we give several characterizations of inclusion of DAG models and verify Meek's conjecture in the case that the DAGs K and L differ in at most one adjacency. As a warming up a rigorous proof of graphical characterizations of equivalence of DAGs is given.
